statement.tex: \text{Find the equations of the normals to the}\\ \text{curve } y = x^3 + 2x + 6 \text{ which are parallel}\\ \text{to the line }x + 14y + 4 = 0

step.context: \text{If }m_L \text{ be the slope of the given line}\\ \text{and }m_N\text{ and }m_T\text{ the slopes of the}\\ \text{normal and tangent at a point, then}\ldots
step.reason: \text{The given line is parallel to the normal.}\\ \text{Which means, }m_L = m_N.\text{ Moreover, as the}\\ \text{normal is }\perp\text{ to the tangent, }m_T\cdot m_N = -1.

step.tex:
\begin{align} x + 14y + 4 &= 0 \implies y = -\frac{x}{14} - \frac{2}{7}\\ \implies m_L = m_N &= -\frac{1}{14} \\ \therefore m_T &= -\dfrac{1}{-\frac{1}{14}} = 14. \end{align}\\ \text{Which means, }\\ \begin{align} \dfrac{dy}{dx} &= m_T = 14 \\ \text{or, }3x^2 + 2 = 14 \implies x^2 &= 4 \text{ or } x=\pm 2. \end{align}\\
\therefore\text{ the points at which }m_N = m_L = -\frac{1}{14}\text{ are}\\ \begin{tabular}{c|c|c} x & y = x^3+2x+6 & (x,y) \\ \hline -2 & -6 & (-2,-6) \\ 2 & 18 & (2,18) \\ \hline \end{tabular}
step.reason: \textbf{Recap: }\text{We went from }\\ m_L \rightarrow m_N \rightarrow m_T \rightarrow \frac{dy}{dx}\rightarrow x.

step.context: \text{To find the equation of the normals}\\ \text{what would you do next?}
step.tex: \text{Find the equation of the lines that}\\ \bullet\text{Pass through }(-2,-6)\text{ with slope = }-\frac{1}{14} \\ \bullet\text{Pass through }(2,18)\text{ with slope = }-\frac{1}{14} \\
\text{Find the equation of the line that }\\ \bullet\text{ Passes through }(-2,-6)\text{ and }(2,18).
step.reason: \text{The two points we found are points where}\\ \text{the normal is }\parallel x+14y+6=0.\\ \text{We know the points, we know the slope.}\\ \text{We can find the lines.}

step.context: \text{Would the calculations below give}\\ \text{you the required normals?}
step.reason: \text{The equation of a line passing through}\\ \text{a point }(a,b)\text{ with slope m is simply} \\ \frac{y-b}{x-a} = m. \text{Simplify to get it in }\\ mx + ny + k = 0\text{ form.}
